posts.name: Balkan Treat Box
posts.note: Balkan Treat Box makes old world traditional dishes seem contemporary, relevant and accessible. You should order the Pide, a Turkish grilled flatbread. From the Eater St. Loius website, 'Each year, one new food truck distinguishes itself from St. Louis's ever-expanding fleet, and in 2017 that truck is certain to be Balkan Treat Box. Chef-owner Loryn Feliciano-Nalic bakes bread in the truck’s wood-burning oven, including Bosnian somun — which she tops with cevapi (minced-beef sausages) and chicken döner — and the Neapolitan-Esque crust for pide, a Turkish flatbread covered in ground beef and cheese.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bogart's Smokehouse
posts.note: Bogart's Smokehouse is a down-home barbecue joint where the crowds eat Memphis and St. Louis specialties at Formica tables. You need to order the ribs or their pastrami sandwich.

posts.name: Bolyard's Meat and Provisions
posts.note: Bolyard's Meat and Provisions offer pork, chicken, beef, and lamb that have been raised on the lush pastures of small Midwestern farms. Non-confinement, rotational grazing, and diets consisting of alfalfa, bluegrass, chicory, clover, and an occasional acorn and grub worm, allow their animals to thrive, without the use of hormones or antibiotics. You need to order the meatloaf sandwich.

posts.name: Carl's Drive-In
posts.note: Carl's Drive-In serves hamburgers, onion rings, and foot-long hot dogs are featured at this Route 66-themed American diner. From their website, 'Located on historic Route 66, Carl’s Drive-In offers delicious American drive-in food and top-notch service. Try our crispy-edged, griddle-smashed double cheeseburger with your choice of toppings or our specialty Curly-Q hot dog. Wash it down with our famous homemade root beer in a frosty mug. Carl’s is the perfect place to grab a quick bite to eat that really hits the spot. Carl’s Drive-In is a St. Louis institution. For six decades, we have kept our history alive through a traditional menu and unique, 16 stool layout. Our simple menu is anything but ordinary, featuring crispy-edged burgers, footlong hotdogs, and our homemade root beer. Stop by today and taste tradition.'

posts.name: Cate Zone Chinese Cafe
posts.note: Cate Zone Chinese Cafe is a casual, contemporary eatery specializing in a wide array of traditional Northeast Chinese cuisine. From the Eater St. Louis website, The hearty cuisine of China's northeast is the specialty at Daniel Ma and Quincy Lin's Cate Zone Chinese Cafe, one of several regional Chinese restaurants to have opened in St. Louis in recent years. The expansive menu ranges from light (honey-crisp sweet potato topped with spun sugar) to intense (Chinese sour cabbage with pork belly). Sweet-and-sour pork is a must-order dish for the first-time visitor.

posts.name: Clementine's Naughty and Nice Creamery
posts.note: Clementine's Naughty and Nice Creamery is a modern micro-creamery serving unique small-batch ice cream flavors, with alcohol-infused options. Their small-batch creations are handcrafted using only the finest quality, 100% all-natural ingredients. They incorporate some of St. Louis’ favorite local ingredients to create smooth, creamy treats for anyone who’s feeling naughty or nice. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: The Donut Stop
posts.note: The Donut Stop's glass cases reveal all sorts of flavors at this old-school bakery: glazed, sugar, cake, twists and French doughnuts—otherwise known as beignets. Also for sale is a Donut Stop exclusive: Cinnamon Globs. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Elaia
posts.note: Elaia is a sophisticated Mediterranean fine-dining spot offering tasting menus and seasonally inspired cocktails. From their website, 'The flagship of Ben Poremba's Bengelina Hospitality Group, Elaia is an award-winning restaurant offering a singular dining experience, featuring imaginative cuisine and extensive wine list in a relaxed and intimate atmosphere. Located in a renovated house in The Botanical Heights Neighborhood in South St. Louis near Historic Tower Grove Park, and The Missouri Botanical Gardens. Elaia is awarded 4 stars (out of 4) by the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. Elaia was ranked #2 in St. Louis in 2015, 2016, 2017, and #3 in 2018 in restaurant critic Ian Froeb's annual “The 100 Best Restaurants in St. Louis.”'

posts.name: FarmHaus Restaurant
posts.note: From the FarmHaus Restaurant website, 'Farmhaus is dedicated to supporting local farms, organic food production, and sustainable agriculture. We focus on using fresh, seasonal ingredients to create a memorable and intriguing dining experience. Our menu changes daily.' From the Eater St. Louis website about FarmHaus Restaurant, 'Chef Kevin Willman comes from an Illinois farming family, which explains his community-focused approach to food. His menu relies on locally grown produce and ingredients and nearby vendors, which means that most of the regular menu items hail from the bi-state area. The cuisine is technically American, but Willman definitely takes creative liberties. The menu changes, but you might see something like a braised lamb steam bun made with kimchi, or pan-seared sea scallops served with creamy grits and barbecue.'

posts.name: Fiddlehead Fern Cafe
posts.note: Fiddlehead Fern Cafe serves elevated café fare in a trendy, minimalist space built on the renovated lot of an old gas station at the corner of Russell and Thurman.

posts.name: Frankly on Cherokee
posts.note: Frankly on Cherokee is a brick-and-mortar outpost of a popular food truck preparing signature sausages made with local meats. They serve scratch-made sausages and Belgain-style, brined, hand-cut, twice-cooked french fries that come with homemade ketchup or dipping sauce.

posts.name: Grace Meat and Three
posts.note: Grace Meat and Three is a counter service restaurant offering a unique blend of refined Southern American fare and down-home hospitality. They combine the best elements of a traditional 'meat and three' and a family-style restaurant.

posts.name: Hi-Pointe Drive-In
posts.note: Hi-Pointe Drive-In is a hip, modern spot for burgers and sandwiches highlighting local ingredients in a former 1980s drive-in. From their website, 'The Hi-Pointe has been an iconic St. Louis destination ever since this spot was a little drive-in in the 1980s. Our mission is to bring it back to life with mouthwatering burgers and original sandwiches. Our chef-inspired menu uses locally sourced ingredients. Thanks for stopping by to say Hi. Our burger and sandwich joint is located in the historic Hi-Pointe neighborhood, just off of highway 40. This spot is a great place to pop into before or after events around town, or even as the main event. The menu has something for folks of many walks of life, from our creative burgers, sandwiches, and shakes, to healthy salads and a menu for the little ones.' From the Eater St. Louis website, Mike Johnson is building a barbecue empire with Sugarfire Smoke House, which now boasts six locations and more on the way. But his latest venture, Hi-Pointe Drive-In, is a non-barbecue spinoff based around Sugarfire's popular griddled burger and the chef’s penchant for over-the-top specials. Sandwiches include the Guac-ness Monster, with Funyuns-crusted fried avocado, and the Abaconing, with bacon, bacon-fat aioli, and fried green tomato dredged in bacon bits. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Iron Barley Eating Establishment
posts.note: Iron Barley Eating Establishment does creative takes on American comfort food, a craft-beer focus and a late-night music club out back. You need to order the schnitzel and spaetzle.

posts.name: Kounter Kulture
posts.note: The Kounter Kulture menu is a rotating list of Asian dishes representing China, Korea, Thailand, Japan, and Vietnam. They believe in sourcing proteins and vegetables from local farms for culinary and environmental reasons so you can expect a sustainable, seasonal menu on each visit. The building is zoned as carry out so you can't dine in, but they do have seating outside. From the Eater St. Louis website, 'Kounter Kulture started as a farmers’ market stand and then opened a brick and mortar operation on Watson Road. The menu draws on cooking traditions from China, Korea, Thailand, Japan, and Vietnam. Order the Gyudon, made with soy-dashi braised Missouri beef, slow-cooked egg, and seasoned rice, or try Kounter Kulture’s take on bibimbap (mixed rice) for a combination of Korean flavors.'

posts.name: Lemmons
posts.note: From the Lemmons website, 'Three siblings, two parents, one big idea. If you haven't heard about us before, here's the quick rundown. The 'rents came from Bosnia; we were born and raised in South St. Louis {we=Erna, Ermin, Senada}. Heard of Grbic Restaurant? That's us. The parents taught us what they know and now we are gonna give it a go... on our own! Executive Chef Senada Grbic is making all of our favorite American foods but adding that Balkan twist, stemming back to our roots.' From the Eater St. Loius website about Lemmons, 'Ermina and Sulejman Grbic's Grbic Restaurant introduced a generation of St. Louis diners to Bosnian cuisine when it opened in 2002. (St. Louis has been home to the largest population of Bosnians in the U.S. since the 1990s.) At Lemmons by Grbic, the Grbics' adult children take center stage, and executive chef Senada Grbic traces her Bosnian-American upbringing through burgers and kabobs, flatbread pizzas, and cevapi.'

posts.name: Mac's Local Eats
posts.note: Mac's Local Eats is a spot for burgers using locally-raised meat, located inside Bluewood Brewing Company. From the Mac's Local Eats website, 'Welcome to Mac's Local Eats. A Local, Pasture Raised, Unconventional, WHOLE Animal Protein, and Seasonal Produce Restaurant. A Burger Joint. We are committed to using seasonal produce, sourcing whole animals from small local farms, and utilizing every part of the animal in the foods we prepare. We only work with farmers who are true stewards of the Earth, those who are committed to the ethical treatment of their animals and allow them to engage in their natural intrinsic behaviors. Because we believe, that's how it should be done. From the whole cow, dry-aged beef smashed burgers to boudin, cracklins, and all the condiments in between. We make almost every component we serve from scratch, in house, to provide food that is undeniably more delicious and inherently more nutritious.' From the Eater St. Louis website, A restaurant (really, a window where you place your order) inside an existing bar in the city's Dogtown neighborhood, Mac's Local Eats stacks smashed burgers as tall as four patties high. Owner Chris McKenzie has already built a business selling shares in whole, locally sourced cows (and other animals), and he makes Mac's 2-ounce patties with the dry-aged beef ground from the whole cow.

posts.name: Mission Taco Joint
posts.note: From the Mission Taco Joint website, 'Growing up in California, skating and surfing up and down the coast, inspired brothers Jason and Adam Tilford to bring their love of Cali street food to their new Midwest home. Mission Taco Joint is a culmination of their travels, experiences, and the flavors of their childhood. MTJ’s first location opened in St. Louis’ Delmar Loop in 2013, serving West Coast style street tacos and pouring beers from STL’s favorite craft breweries. Word quickly spread about the quality food and genuine hospitality and became a favorite place for students, young professionals, and families alike.' From the Eater St. Louis website about Mission Taco Joint, 'With locations in the Soulard, Delmar Loop, and Central West End neighborhoods, Mission Taco Joint has your street-style taco cravings covered when you’re traveling about town. Order tacos a la carte, preferably at happy hour, when tacos are just $2 each. For something more filling, try the carne asada fries made with chile-crusted fries and flank steak.'

posts.name: Nudo House STL
posts.note: Nudo House STL is a noodle specialist supplying hot bowls, cold appetizers, and housemade soft serve in a modern space. Nudo is the celebration of how powerful food can be, and it’s fueled by their gratitude for its ability to make anyone feel at home anywhere. At Nudo, you’ll find rich ramen alongside aromatic pho, on a menu that’s been years in the making. You’ll find ramen that one of Japan’s foremost ramen chefs had a hand in crafting. From the Eater St. Loius website, 'Nudo House is the long-awaited ramen restaurant from Qui Tran, whose family founded Mai Lee, St. Louis’s first (and still beloved) Vietnamese restaurant. Tran and co-owner and executive chef Marie-Anne Velasco are serious about ramen — they've even taken lessons from Japanese ramen master Shigetoshi Nakamura — but Nudo House also nods to Tran's Mai Lee background with several variations of pho.'

posts.name: Olio
posts.note: Olio is an easygoing wine bar in a stylishly remodeled service station serving Mediterranean small plates. From their website, 'Located in a renovated 1930’s Standard Oil Filling Station, Olio is an unusual and unusually charming setting for a grown-up eatery and cocktail bar (kids are most welcome). Olio opened in the fall of 2012. it is half of the story of chef/owner Ben Poremba’s ambitious culinary and urban renewal project. Next door to Olio, and connected to it, is Olio's sister restaurant, Elaia, a 30-seat fine dining chef-driven restaurant. An equally unusual setting for a restaurant, Elaia is situated in a renovated 1890’s house- the same house that was once occupied by the original owner/operator of the gas station, Mr. Kinsworhty.'

posts.name: Pappy's Smokehouse
posts.note: Pappy's Smokehouse is an order-at-the-counter favorite for wood-smoked Memphis-style barbecue in down-home digs.

posts.name: Pastaria
posts.note: Pastaria is an updated Italian cooking in a slick, modern trattoria with a soaring ceiling and an open kitchen. Andrew Zimmern says you can't go wrong with this Bucatini all’Amatriciana.

posts.name: Pint Size Bakery and Coffee
posts.note: Pint Size Bakery and Coffee serve inventive baked goods, such as salted caramel croissants, on offer in this quaint, funky cafe. Pint Size Bakery and Coffee their motto is 'Small Batch-From Scratch-Fresh Daily,' and they put that to work each day by baking muffins, cookies, scones, and more fresh items each morning. If they sell a lot of cookies, they bake more what that means to you as a customer is that there are no fresher baked goods anywhere in Saint Louis.

posts.name: Pizza Head
posts.note: From the Pizza Head website, 'Pizza Head serves large 20 inch NYC style pies, bagels (FRIDAY), and cheap beer in a can.  We opened in May of 2017 to a line all the way around the block! We were blown away by the love. The flow hasn't stopped! The energy and pizza is addictive. We love all and serve all. Everyday pizza for everyday people.' From the Eater St. Louis website, 'After making his name with the vegetarian Neapolitan pizzeria Pizzeoli, Scott Sandler has turned to New York-style pizza. Pizza Head, located along the city's vibrant South Grand strip and exuding a dingy-rock-club vibe, serves pizza by the slice and 20-inch whole pies. Like Pizzeoli, Pizza Head is vegetarian. The “pepperoni” and “sausage” are actually faux meat, and vegans can order cashew-based “cheese.”'

posts.name: Polite Society Restaurant and Bar
posts.note: From the Polite Society Restaurant and Bar website, 'Polite Society is a restaurant, bar, and gathering place located at 1923 Park Avenue, in the historic Lafayette Square neighborhood of St. Louis. We exist to provide our neighbors, friends, and families with a warm environment of thoughtful service, exceptional food, drink, and company.' From the Eater St. Louis website, 'Industry veterans Jonathan Schoen and Brian Schmitz waited six years to bring Polite Society to fruition. Their patience earned them a prime location in the historic Lafayette Square neighborhood and a menu refined to appeal to appetites both contemporary (chicken wings, an heirloom tomato salad) and classic (chicken schnitzel, steak with foyot sauce). The name isn't ironic: This is a warm neighborhood bistro.'

posts.name: Retreat Gastropub
posts.note: From the Retreat Gastropub website, 'Located in St. Louis's Central West End, Retreat is the modern American pub opened in 2015. We are a cocktail bar, with an extensive craft beer selection, and all made from scratch American food. Retreat Gastropub is located inside the 6 North building on the corner of Sarah and Laclede. Retreat is in the heart of St. Louis central corridor, centered around the 'Cortex' district of bioscience and technology research and start-ups, the historic Central West end, and minutes away from up-and-coming neighborhoods The Grove and Botanical Heights. We aim to provide guests with a memorable experience by offering a comfortable atmosphere while combining a flavorful food menu with our focus on craft cocktails and craft beer.' From the Eater St. Louis website, 'The menu at Retreat covers a lot of territory. At dinnertime, you can opt for comfort food options, like mac and cheese, fried chicken wings, or a pepper steak, or try something like the feta mousse crostini with fig marmalade. But plan your visit around the libations: The beer menu changes often to include new and interesting brews from as far as New York City and California, and the house cocktails infuse new flavors into the classics. Like the Dinosaur Theory cocktail, made with Chicago’s Letherbee Gin, genepy, pineapple, lemon, chamomile, and kale — yes, really — you won’t find this on a drink menu anywhere else in the city.'

posts.name: Salt and Smoke
posts.note: Salt and Smoke is a hip, relaxed Texas-style BBQ joint with lots of bourbons, artisan cocktails, and craft beer.

posts.name: Savage Restaurant
posts.note: From the Savage Restaurant website, 'Savage is a small restaurant located inside what used to be the old A&B Liquor Mart. The menu is typically vegetable and seafood-focused, and the atmosphere relaxed. We serve dinner starting at 5, lunch starting at noon and have a patio that is open all night with food and drink menus available.'

posts.name: The Shaved Duck
posts.note: The Shaved Duck is a brick-walled setting for barbecue and Southern specialties served alongside American craft beers. Order the pulled pork and BBQ rib meat cheese fries. There called smothered fries or get the smoked duck breast with juniper berry cherry jam. From the Eater St. Louis website, 'Choose from an array of smokehouse specialties at The Shaved Duck — a restaurant you may have seen on The Food Network’s Diners, Drive-Ins And Dives — but not before you try an appetizer. The buttermilk cornbread is a fifteen-minute wait, but only because it’s literally fresh out of the oven and will come to your table in a cast-iron skillet with side of honey butter. Follow that up with the melt-in-your-mouth pulled pork sandwich. It’s slowly smoked over wild cherry and hickory for a smoky, sweet flavor.'
posts.rcmmnd: Eater St. Louis and Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives

posts.name: Strange Donuts
posts.note: Strange Donuts was listed on Eater's top 18 donut places in the United States. From Eater's website, 'Strange Donuts offers six classic and six “creative” selections each day (inspired by “new tastes and wild styles coming from places like Portland, Austin, and L.A.,” according to their website). They've also paired with Quincy Street Bistro to offer the Strange Hog Burger: “Yeast donut stuffed with hog burger, topped with maple glaze, caramelized onions and pimento cheese whiz !!”'

posts.name: Sugarfire Smoke House
posts.note: Sugarfire Smoke House is a rustic local BBQ chain serving ribs, salmon, brisket cheesesteaks, spiked shakes and more. You need to check out their sandwiches. NOTE: They have multiple locations, and they open at 11:00 AM and close when they sell out.

posts.name: Ted Drewes Frozen Custard
posts.note: Ted Drewes Frozen Custard is a popular take-out spot with a variety of frozen custards dished out through a walk-up window. NOTE: They have multiple locations.
posts.rcmmnd: Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives and Justin Thorp

posts.name: Union Loafers Café and Bread Bakery
posts.note: Union Loafers Café and Bread Bakery is a contemporary haunt serving traditionally baked bread's, lunchtime sandwiches, and dinnertime pizzas. You need to order the rustic pizza or one of the meats or veggie ciabatta bread sandwiches.

posts.name: Vicia
posts.note: From the Vicia website, 'Our menu is driven by the best of what's available at the moment and sourced from relationships we have with farmers, fishermen, and artisans in the Midwest region and beyond. By focusing on what’s fresh, we aim to present a memorable dining experience that can be enjoyed in a new way each time. Since opening in March of 2017, Vicia has received numerous national and regional accolades, including 4-stars from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, a semi-finalist nomination from the James Beard Foundation for Best New Restaurant 2018, a Best New Restaurant in America by Eater, Esquire, and Bon Appetit, as well as Michael being named a Best New Chef in America 2018 by Food and Wine.' From the Eater St. Louis website, 'Former Blue Hill at Stone Barns chef de cuisine Michael Gallina returned to his native St. Louis with his wife, Tara (a former Blue Hill at Stone Barns captain), to open Vicia. The ambitious restaurant features wood-fired, vegetable-forward fare across multiple formats: a casual, counter-service lunch; an a la carte dinner menu; and a chef's tasting menu. The critical praise has been overwhelmingly strong, including a rare four-star review from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, and Eater critic Bill Addison named Vicia one of the 12 best new restaurants in the countr

posts.name: Vincent Van Doughnut
posts.note: Vincent Van Doughnut is an intimate shop offering donuts in a daily choice of gourmet flavors, plus coffee, and espresso.

posts.name: World's Fair Donuts
posts.note: World's Fair Donuts is a small, mom and pop spot is a popular place for donuts, fritters, and coffee. NOTE: Cash only.
